data.title: CW
data.description: All work relating to coursework from university, sixth form, or otherwise.

data.title: Winner
data.description: This project recieved an award at a hackathon.

data.caption: Private Repository
data.description: Programming, Algorithms, and Data Structures. console application. 13 complex tasks e.g. N-Queen Problem, Hamiltonian Paths, and string edit distance.C++ templates which automatically detected the data type of user input. I also sanitised, type checked, and error checked their input.
data.title: 210CT

data.caption: Private Repository
data.description: My first MEAN stack application.
data.title: TourOfBritain

data.description: One part of module from second year at university was to design my own hashing algorithm. I am in the process of converting it to C from C++.
data.title: JonHash

data.description: This website! Completely redesigned and overhauled to use Svelte 3.
data.title: jonmarsh.dev

data.description: Get objects from an array in O(1) time. Achieved by transposing the array using the keys of each object. Uses a lot of memory.
data.title: Oaty

data.description: A browser compatibilty anaylser. Scans your repositories for any CSS, HTML, and JavaScript and figures out the minimum version each browser supports.
data.title: Browsability

data.description: FaktNews grades the trustworthiness of the website you're currently viewing. This project is a recreation of my team's submission at AstonHack 2017; I originally designed and created the front-end, but decided I wanted to redo the whole project to create a faster, more robust solution.
data.title: FaktNews

data.description: 3D Flappy Bird using the pulfrich effect. Get a pair of dark tinted sunglasses and pop out the left lens, and play away!
data.title: PulfrichBird

data.description: Visualises the licenses of all dependencies and displays any potential problems
data.title: Dependency License Explorer

data.description: Collection of graphical widgets used in other projects. The current ones came from FaktNews. New features added as and when, this project has no objectives.
data.title: Widgets

data.description: A recreation of agar.io, this project is a continuation of my work from HackNotts 2017. I aim to completely recreate the game, at the moment I would say it has about 5% of the planned features. Error checking has been added but it's a bit strict at the moment, just (soft) refresh and try again if anything happens.
data.title: Totally Not Agario

data.description: Face swap using OpenCV. Another independent recreation of a team submission at BrumHack 2017. Hit a bit of a wall in development, but I am currently researching OpenCV by looking at similar projects.
data.title: Face Swap

data.description: This game was designed to help my GCSE business studies classmates learn the definitions. This was made within a week so there's not much to it.
data.title: Quiz

data.description: My first 2D platformer. The levels are difficult, and the poor performance and control make it hard, but it is possible! Good luck... (It says at the end of the first level, but might not make it that far: press 'q' when near the flag to end the level)
data.title: Adventure

data.description: My first 2D sidescroller. The collision detection is awful, but there's a colour option in settings to make up for it.
data.title: Asteroid Run

data.description: `Real World Project` Coursework. This app is a community based report system that allows the general public to submit problems to their local council. For example fly tipping, pot holes, or faulty lights. As lead programmer of the team it was my responsibility to select the appropriate tools for the job. The system would require evidence of the problem (pictures) so we needed to create a cross-platform mobile phone app. There were other restrictions to overcome as well: not all of the developers have access to the same level of equipment. One of us only had a Chromebook. After researching for two weeks I came up with the following combination: VS Code, React Native (and therefore Node.js), SQLite3,
data.title: Real World Project

data.description: Local multiplayer tank battle game. You can add players until you run out of keys (or re-use them if you're up for a challenge). The environment is a procedurally generate maze with x (user-defined) random walls removed. Bullets bounce twice before they get absorbed.
data.title: Tank Trouble

data.description: A simple Minesweeper clone
data.title: Minesweeper

data.description: A simple cipher encryption and decryption file application.
data.title: Encrypt

data.description: A simple procedural maze generator that I created in a couple of days during my year 10 works experience.
data.title: Maze
